natural problem: Find all values of $x$ that satisfy \[\frac{x^2}{x+1} \ge \frac{2}{x-1} + \frac{5}{4}.\]
natural solution: Combining the terms on the right-hand side, we have \[\frac{x^2}{x+1} \ge \frac{5x+3}{4(x-1)}.\]Then, moving all the terms to the left-hand side and combining denominators again, we get \[\begin{aligned} \frac{x^2}{x+1} - \frac{5x+3}{4(x-1)} &\ge 0 \\ \frac{4x^2(x-1)-(x+1)(5x+3)}{(x+1)(x-1)} &\ge 0 \\ \frac{4x^3-9x^2-8x-3}{(x+1)(x-1)} &\ge 0.

Using the rational root theorem to test for rational roots, we see that $x=3$ is a root of $4x^3-9x^2-8x-3.$ Then, doing the polynomial division gives \[4x^3-9x^2-8x-3 = (x-3)(4x^2+3x+1),\]so we have \[\frac{(x-3)(4x^2+3x+1)}{(x+1)(x-1)} \ge 0.\]Since $4x^2+3x+1$ has a positive $x^2$ coefficient, and its discriminant is $3^2 - 4 \cdot 4= -7,$ which is negative, it follows that $4x^2 + 3x + 1 > 0$ for all $x.$ Thus, the above inequality is equivalent to \[f(x) = \frac{x-3}{(x+1)(x-1)} \ge 0.\]We make a sign table for $f(x)$: \begin{tabular}{c|ccc|c} &$x-3$ &$x+1$ &$x-1$ &$f(x)$ \\ \hline$x<-1$ &$-$&$-$&$-$&$-$\\ [.1cm]$-1<x<1$ &$-$&$+$&$-$&$+$\\ [.1cm]$1<x<3$ &$-$&$+$&$+$&$-$\\ [.1cm]$x>3$ &$+$&$+$&$+$&$+$\\ [.1cm]\end{tabular}We see that $f(x) > 0$ when $-1 < x < 1$ or $x > 3.$ Since the inequality is nonstrict, we also include the values of $x$ such that $f(x) = 0,$ that is, only $x = 3.$ Therefore, the solution to the inequality is \[x \in \boxed{(-1, 1) \cup [3, \infty)}.\]

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real
assumes h0 : "x \<noteq> -1"
and h1 : "x \<noteq> 1"
and h2 : "x powr 2 / (x + 1) \<ge> 2 / (x - 1) + 5 / 4"
shows  "(x > -1 \<and> x < 1) \<or> (x \<ge> 3)"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find all values of $x$ that satisfy \[\frac{x^2}{x+1} \ge \frac{2}{x-1} + \frac{5}{4}.\] The final Answer is (-1, 1) \cup [3, \infty)
 ### Proof
 Combining the terms on the right-hand side, we have \[\frac{x^2}{x+1} \ge \frac{5x+3}{4(x-1)}.\]Then, moving all the terms to the left-hand side and combining denominators again, we get \[\begin{aligned} \frac{x^2}{x+1} - \frac{5x+3}{4(x-1)} &\ge 0 \\ \frac{4x^2(x-1)-(x+1)(5x+3)}{(x+1)(x-1)} &\ge 0 \\ \frac{4x^3-9x^2-8x-3}{(x+1)(x-1)} &\ge 0.
 \end{aligned}\]We try to factor the numerator.
 Using the rational root theorem to test for rational roots, we see that $x=3$ is a root of $4x^3-9x^2-8x-3.$ Then, doing the polynomial division gives \[4x^3-9x^2-8x-3 = (x-3)(4x^2+3x+1),\]so we have \[\frac{(x-3)(4x^2+3x+1)}{(x+1)(x-1)} \ge 0.\]Since $4x^2+3x+1$ has a positive $x^2$ coefficient, and its discriminant is $3^2 - 4 \cdot 4= -7,$ which is negative, it follows that $4x^2 + 3x + 1 > 0$ for all $x.$ Thus, the above inequality is equivalent to \[f(x) = \frac{x-3}{(x+1)(x-1)} \ge 0.\]We make a sign table for $f(x)$: \begin{tabular}{c|ccc|c} &$x-3$ &$x+1$ &$x-1$ &$f(x)$ \\ \hline$x<-1$ &$-$&$-$&$-$&$-$\\ [.1cm]$-1<x<1$ &$-$&$+$&$-$&$+$\\ [.1cm]$1<x<3$ &$-$&$+$&$+$&$-$\\ [.1cm]$x>3$ &$+$&$+$&$+$&$+$\\ [.1cm]\end{tabular}We see that $f(x) > 0$ when $-1 < x < 1$ or $x > 3.$ Since the inequality is nonstrict, we also include the values of $x$ such that $f(x) = 0,$ that is, only $x = 3.$ Therefore, the solution to the inequality is \[x \in \boxed{(-1, 1) \cup [3, \infty)}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real
assumes h0 : "x \<noteq> -1"
and h1 : "x \<noteq> 1"
and h2 : "x powr 2 / (x + 1) \<ge> 2 / (x - 1) + 5 / 4"
shows  "(x > -1 \<and> x < 1) \<or> (x \<ge> 3)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: For which values of $x$, not equal to $-1$ or $1$, does the inequality $\frac{x^2}{x+1} \geq \frac{2}{x-1} + \frac{5}{4}$ hold? The valid values of $x$ are those that are either between $-1$ and $1$ or greater than or equal to $3$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real
assumes h0 : "x ≠ -1"
and h1 : "x ≠ 1"
and h2 : "x powr 2 / (x + 1) \<ge> 2 / (x - 1) + 5 / 4"
shows  "(x > -1 \<and> x < 1) \<or> x \<ge> 3"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find all values of $x$ that satisfy \[\frac{x^2}{x+1} \ge \frac{2}{x-1} + \frac{5}{4}.\] The final Answer is (-1, 1) \cup [3, \infty)
 ### Proof
 Combining the terms on the right-hand side, we have \[\frac{x^2}{x+1} \ge \frac{5x+3}{4(x-1)}.\]Then, moving all the terms to the left-hand side and combining denominators again, we get \[\begin{aligned} \frac{x^2}{x+1} - \frac{5x+3}{4(x-1)} &\ge 0 \\ \frac{4x^2(x-1)-(x+1)(5x+3)}{(x+1)(x-1)} &\ge 0 \\ \frac{4x^3-9x^2-8x-3}{(x+1)(x-1)} &\ge 0.
 \end{aligned}\]We try to factor the numerator.
 Using the rational root theorem to test for rational roots, we see that $x=3$ is a root of $4x^3-9x^2-8x-3.$ Then, doing the polynomial division gives \[4x^3-9x^2-8x-3 = (x-3)(4x^2+3x+1),\]so we have \[\frac{(x-3)(4x^2+3x+1)}{(x+1)(x-1)} \ge 0.\]Since $4x^2+3x+1$ has a positive $x^2$ coefficient, and its discriminant is $3^2 - 4 \cdot 4= -7,$ which is negative, it follows that $4x^2 + 3x + 1 > 0$ for all $x.$ Thus, the above inequality is equivalent to \[f(x) = \frac{x-3}{(x+1)(x-1)} \ge 0.\]We make a sign table for $f(x)$: \begin{tabular}{c|ccc|c} &$x-3$ &$x+1$ &$x-1$ &$f(x)$ \\ \hline$x<-1$ &$-$&$-$&$-$&$-$\\ [.1cm]$-1<x<1$ &$-$&$+$&$-$&$+$\\ [.1cm]$1<x<3$ &$-$&$+$&$+$&$-$\\ [.1cm]$x>3$ &$+$&$+$&$+$&$+$\\ [.1cm]\end{tabular}We see that $f(x) > 0$ when $-1 < x < 1$ or $x > 3.$ Since the inequality is nonstrict, we also include the values of $x$ such that $f(x) = 0,$ that is, only $x = 3.$ Therefore, the solution to the inequality is \[x \in \boxed{(-1, 1) \cup [3, \infty)}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real
assumes h0 : "x ≠ -1"
and h1 : "x ≠ 1"
and h2 : "x powr 2 / (x + 1) \<ge> 2 / (x - 1) + 5 / 4"
shows  "(x > -1 \<and> x < 1) \<or> x \<ge> 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: For all real numbers $x$, except $-1$ and $1$, if $\frac{x^2}{x+1} \geq \frac{2}{x-1} + \frac{5}{4}$, show that $-1 < x < 1$ or $x \geq 3$.

theorem
fixes x :: real
assumes h0 : "x \<noteq> -1"
and h1 : "x \<noteq> 1"
and h2 : "x powr 2 / (x + 1) \<ge> 2 / (x - 1) + 5 / 4"
shows  "x \<in> {-1<..<1} \<union> {x. x \<ge> 3}"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: "Find the possible values of $x$ that satisfy the inequality $\frac{x^2}{x+1} \geq \frac{2}{x-1} + \frac{5}{4}$, given that $x \neq -1$ and $x \neq 1$. The final answer is that $x$ is in the interval $(-1,1)$ or $x$ is greater than or equal to $3$."

theorem
fixes x :: real
assumes h0 : "x \<noteq> -1"
and h1 : "x \<noteq> 1"
and h2 : "(x powr 2) / (x + 1) \<ge> 2 / (x - 1) + 5 / 4"
shows  "x \<in> {-1<..<1} \<union> {3..}"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: If $x$ is a real number such that $x \neq -1$ and $x \neq 1$ and $\frac{x^2}{x+1} \geq \frac{2}{x-1} + \frac{5}{4}$, then prove that $x$ is either in the interval $(-1, 1)$ or is greater than or equal to $3$.

theorem
fixes x :: real
assumes h0 : "x ≠ -1"
and h1 : "x ≠ 1"
and h2 : "x powr 2 / (x + 1) \<ge> 2 / (x - 1) + 5 / 4"
shows  "x \<in> {-1 <..< 1} \<union> {x. x \<ge> 3}"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Find all real numbers $x$ such that $\frac{x^2}{x+1} \geq \frac{2}{x-1} + \frac{5}{4}$, where $x$ is not equal to $-1$ or $1$. The solution set is $x$ in the open interval between $-1$ and $1$, inclusive, or $x$ is greater than or equal to $3$.

theorem
fixes x :: real
assumes h0 : "x ≠ -1"
and h1 : "x ≠ 1"
and h2 : "x powr 2 / (x + 1) \<ge> 2 / (x - 1) + 5/4"
shows  "x \<in> {-1<..<1} \<union> {3..}"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Given that $x$ is a real number which is not equal to $-1$ and $1$, and that the inequality $\frac{x^2}{x+1} \geq \frac{2}{x-1} + \frac{5}{4}$ holds, find the range of $x$. The final answer is that $x$ belongs to the intervals $(-1, 1)$ and $[3, \infty)$.

theorem
fixes x :: real
assumes h0 : "x ≠ -1"
and h1 : "x ≠ 1"
and h2 : "(x powr 2) / (x + 1) \<ge> 2 / (x - 1) + 5 / 4"
shows  "x \<in> {-1<..<1} \<union> {3..}"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Find the range of $x$ that satisfies the inequality $\frac{x^2}{x+1} \geq \frac{2}{x-1} + \frac{5}{4}$, given that $x$ cannot be equal to $-1$ or $1$. The possible values of $x$ are in the interval $(-1, 1)$ or in the interval $(3, \infty)$.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real
assumes h0 : "x \<noteq> -1"
and h1 : "x \<noteq> 1"
and h2 : "x\<^sup>2 / (x + 1) \<ge> 2 / (x - 1) + 5 / 4"
shows  "(x > -1 \<and> x < 1) \<or> (x \<ge> 3)"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find all values of $x$ that satisfy \[\frac{x^2}{x+1} \ge \frac{2}{x-1} + \frac{5}{4}.\] The final Answer is (-1, 1) \cup [3, \infty)
 ### Proof
 Combining the terms on the right-hand side, we have \[\frac{x^2}{x+1} \ge \frac{5x+3}{4(x-1)}.\]Then, moving all the terms to the left-hand side and combining denominators again, we get \[\begin{aligned} \frac{x^2}{x+1} - \frac{5x+3}{4(x-1)} &\ge 0 \\ \frac{4x^2(x-1)-(x+1)(5x+3)}{(x+1)(x-1)} &\ge 0 \\ \frac{4x^3-9x^2-8x-3}{(x+1)(x-1)} &\ge 0.
 \end{aligned}\]We try to factor the numerator.
 Using the rational root theorem to test for rational roots, we see that $x=3$ is a root of $4x^3-9x^2-8x-3.$ Then, doing the polynomial division gives \[4x^3-9x^2-8x-3 = (x-3)(4x^2+3x+1),\]so we have \[\frac{(x-3)(4x^2+3x+1)}{(x+1)(x-1)} \ge 0.\]Since $4x^2+3x+1$ has a positive $x^2$ coefficient, and its discriminant is $3^2 - 4 \cdot 4= -7,$ which is negative, it follows that $4x^2 + 3x + 1 > 0$ for all $x.$ Thus, the above inequality is equivalent to \[f(x) = \frac{x-3}{(x+1)(x-1)} \ge 0.\]We make a sign table for $f(x)$: \begin{tabular}{c|ccc|c} &$x-3$ &$x+1$ &$x-1$ &$f(x)$ \\ \hline$x<-1$ &$-$&$-$&$-$&$-$\\ [.1cm]$-1<x<1$ &$-$&$+$&$-$&$+$\\ [.1cm]$1<x<3$ &$-$&$+$&$+$&$-$\\ [.1cm]$x>3$ &$+$&$+$&$+$&$+$\\ [.1cm]\end{tabular}We see that $f(x) > 0$ when $-1 < x < 1$ or $x > 3.$ Since the inequality is nonstrict, we also include the values of $x$ such that $f(x) = 0,$ that is, only $x = 3.$ Therefore, the solution to the inequality is \[x \in \boxed{(-1, 1) \cup [3, \infty)}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real
assumes h0 : "x \<noteq> -1"
and h1 : "x \<noteq> 1"
and h2 : "x\<^sup>2 / (x + 1) \<ge> 2 / (x - 1) + 5 / 4"
shows  "(x > -1 \<and> x < 1) \<or> (x \<ge> 3)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Find the range of real numbers $x$ that satisfy the inequality $\frac{x^2}{x+1} \geq \frac{2}{x-1} + \frac{5}{4}$ where $x \neq -1$ and $x \neq 1$. The solution is $-1 < x < 1$ or $x \geq 3$.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real
assumes h0 : "x \<noteq> -1"
and h1 : "x \<noteq> 1"
and h2 : "x powr 2 / (x + 1) \<ge> 2 / (x - 1) + 5 / 4"
shows  "(x > -1 \<and> x < 1) \<or> (x \<ge> 3)"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find all values of $x$ that satisfy \[\frac{x^2}{x+1} \ge \frac{2}{x-1} + \frac{5}{4}.\] The final Answer is (-1, 1) \cup [3, \infty)
 ### Proof
 Combining the terms on the right-hand side, we have \[\frac{x^2}{x+1} \ge \frac{5x+3}{4(x-1)}.\]Then, moving all the terms to the left-hand side and combining denominators again, we get \[\begin{aligned} \frac{x^2}{x+1} - \frac{5x+3}{4(x-1)} &\ge 0 \\ \frac{4x^2(x-1)-(x+1)(5x+3)}{(x+1)(x-1)} &\ge 0 \\ \frac{4x^3-9x^2-8x-3}{(x+1)(x-1)} &\ge 0.
 \end{aligned}\]We try to factor the numerator.
 Using the rational root theorem to test for rational roots, we see that $x=3$ is a root of $4x^3-9x^2-8x-3.$ Then, doing the polynomial division gives \[4x^3-9x^2-8x-3 = (x-3)(4x^2+3x+1),\]so we have \[\frac{(x-3)(4x^2+3x+1)}{(x+1)(x-1)} \ge 0.\]Since $4x^2+3x+1$ has a positive $x^2$ coefficient, and its discriminant is $3^2 - 4 \cdot 4= -7,$ which is negative, it follows that $4x^2 + 3x + 1 > 0$ for all $x.$ Thus, the above inequality is equivalent to \[f(x) = \frac{x-3}{(x+1)(x-1)} \ge 0.\]We make a sign table for $f(x)$: \begin{tabular}{c|ccc|c} &$x-3$ &$x+1$ &$x-1$ &$f(x)$ \\ \hline$x<-1$ &$-$&$-$&$-$&$-$\\ [.1cm]$-1<x<1$ &$-$&$+$&$-$&$+$\\ [.1cm]$1<x<3$ &$-$&$+$&$+$&$-$\\ [.1cm]$x>3$ &$+$&$+$&$+$&$+$\\ [.1cm]\end{tabular}We see that $f(x) > 0$ when $-1 < x < 1$ or $x > 3.$ Since the inequality is nonstrict, we also include the values of $x$ such that $f(x) = 0,$ that is, only $x = 3.$ Therefore, the solution to the inequality is \[x \in \boxed{(-1, 1) \cup [3, \infty)}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real
assumes h0 : "x \<noteq> -1"
and h1 : "x \<noteq> 1"
and h2 : "x powr 2 / (x + 1) \<ge> 2 / (x - 1) + 5 / 4"
shows  "(x > -1 \<and> x < 1) \<or> (x \<ge> 3)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Find all real numbers $x$ not equal to $-1$ or $1$ that satisfy the inequality $\frac{x^2}{x+1} \geq \frac{2}{x-1} + \frac{5}{4}$. The solution is all $x$ satisfying either $-1 < x < 1$ or $x \geq 3$.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real
assumes h0 : "x \<noteq> -1"
and h1 : "x \<noteq> 1"
and h2 : "(x powr 2) / (x + 1) \<ge> 2 / (x - 1) + 5 / 4"
shows  "x \<in> {-1<..<1} \<union> {x. x \<ge> 3}"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find all values of $x$ that satisfy \[\frac{x^2}{x+1} \ge \frac{2}{x-1} + \frac{5}{4}.\] The final Answer is (-1, 1) \cup [3, \infty)
 ### Proof
 Combining the terms on the right-hand side, we have \[\frac{x^2}{x+1} \ge \frac{5x+3}{4(x-1)}.\]Then, moving all the terms to the left-hand side and combining denominators again, we get \[\begin{aligned} \frac{x^2}{x+1} - \frac{5x+3}{4(x-1)} &\ge 0 \\ \frac{4x^2(x-1)-(x+1)(5x+3)}{(x+1)(x-1)} &\ge 0 \\ \frac{4x^3-9x^2-8x-3}{(x+1)(x-1)} &\ge 0.
 \end{aligned}\]We try to factor the numerator.
 Using the rational root theorem to test for rational roots, we see that $x=3$ is a root of $4x^3-9x^2-8x-3.$ Then, doing the polynomial division gives \[4x^3-9x^2-8x-3 = (x-3)(4x^2+3x+1),\]so we have \[\frac{(x-3)(4x^2+3x+1)}{(x+1)(x-1)} \ge 0.\]Since $4x^2+3x+1$ has a positive $x^2$ coefficient, and its discriminant is $3^2 - 4 \cdot 4= -7,$ which is negative, it follows that $4x^2 + 3x + 1 > 0$ for all $x.$ Thus, the above inequality is equivalent to \[f(x) = \frac{x-3}{(x+1)(x-1)} \ge 0.\]We make a sign table for $f(x)$: \begin{tabular}{c|ccc|c} &$x-3$ &$x+1$ &$x-1$ &$f(x)$ \\ \hline$x<-1$ &$-$&$-$&$-$&$-$\\ [.1cm]$-1<x<1$ &$-$&$+$&$-$&$+$\\ [.1cm]$1<x<3$ &$-$&$+$&$+$&$-$\\ [.1cm]$x>3$ &$+$&$+$&$+$&$+$\\ [.1cm]\end{tabular}We see that $f(x) > 0$ when $-1 < x < 1$ or $x > 3.$ Since the inequality is nonstrict, we also include the values of $x$ such that $f(x) = 0,$ that is, only $x = 3.$ Therefore, the solution to the inequality is \[x \in \boxed{(-1, 1) \cup [3, \infty)}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real
assumes h0 : "x \<noteq> -1"
and h1 : "x \<noteq> 1"
and h2 : "(x powr 2) / (x + 1) \<ge> 2 / (x - 1) + 5 / 4"
shows  "x \<in> {-1<..<1} \<union> {x. x \<ge> 3}"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Find all real numbers $x$ not equal to $-1$ and $1$, such that $\frac{x^2}{x+1} \geq \frac{2}{x-1} + \frac{5}{4}$. The solution set is $x \in (-1,1) \cup [3, \infty)$.
